item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description: @manlius @carlos @thilo @hirokisayama @WiringtheBrain @kordinglab @NicoleCRust @lmrocha @tiago I'll think more carefully. But it's it useful to think about digital vs analog computing? After all the theory of binary computing is very well developed but that of "computing over the reals" has really struggled.There was some excitement excitement in the early 1990s when Stephen Smale was pushing out with several others. There are also some recent connections with attempts to understand Navier-Stokes a bit better. Did you see the link to "water computes" work in a recent post of mine on bsky? It was serious work, but don't know how useful to you.

item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description:
@manlius @cian
Right. But in the end that's why I like moving away from "it's a machine/not a machine" to classes of definitions that discuss interesting ways to distinguish classes of "machines".Like you say, if we don't do this we will eternally going in circles of how language is used.

item.title: Luis M. Rocha
item.description: @manlius I agree words are difficult here. But a UTM is not just about converting finite states to other finite states. That is the machine (the head) part of the UTM. The magic is the addition of the external tape, which depends on an arbitrary code (agreed upon by users). It can be written onto or mutated independently, thus you cannot predict its future states, unless you'd know the states of everything that can alter it. Tape is also as large as you can make it, or infinite in the formal version.I agree with Von Neumann, Pattee, Sydney Brenner that this separate tape is what makes living systems a form of general purpose computers (a.k.a. open ended evolution.) The code is pretty much the same for all life as we know it. Regarding game of life and the like. Per se, it models the mechanistic finite state transitions of matter. One can implement a UTM on it, but that requires establishing an external arbitrary code (consensually agreed by all readers) between finite states of its artificial "matter" (stable dynamical patterns like gliders) and logical truth values (a minimum of true and false and basic logic gates). In other words, specific patterns of the game of life "matter" are used to encode logical expressions---that are modular in the sense that can be arranged as building blocks for infinite logic trees . But this is precisely what we do with physical computers since Babbage&Lovelace: encode modular logic in bistable metal cog wheels, vacuum tubes, or semi-conductors, etc.The genetic code does not encode mathematical logic, like all our computers do, but rather the "logic" of aminoacid sequences. These are highly modular too and can be used to build molecular switches and much more. But not really (rate-independent) logic, rather rate-dependent biochemistry. Still, the code itself is just an arbitrary (we believe) translation of 64 possible codons to 20 aminoacids, a simple machine. It is the separate, effectively infinite tape that gives life its open-endedness since new machines can always be encoded, varied, and selected.I suppose all this just to say that Turing machines are not (just) machines but we can make them from machines :) as Von Neumann said, machines that can increase in complexity (which simple machines can't.)

item.title: Florian Marquardt
item.description: Looking forward to our workshop 'Frontiers of Neuromorphic Computing' that will start tomorrow morning at the @MPI_ScienceOfLight Max Planck Institute for the Science of Light. We are trying to record at least most of the talks and release them later (with some delay) on video.https://indico.mpl.mpg.de/event/15/#neuromorphic #NeuralNetworks #machinelearning

item.title: Free Software Foundation Europe

item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description:
Question to the physicists: phase transitions cannot be predicted from the behavior of individual particles, correct? Do physicists view this as "cooperative behavior"? Thanks.@manlius
@DrYohanJohn
@tiago
#complexity

item.title: El Duvelle
item.description:
@osma @Wolven That seems great, thanks!
I think I’ve seen it before but got stuck at this step:
“Please enter the base URL where this will be hosted.”
How do we choose a URL so that other people can see our archive as well?
For example I have a GitHub account - could the archive go there somehow?

item.title: Osma A
item.description:
@elduvelle @Wolven
Sure: https://tinysubversions.com/twitter-archive/make-your-own/Also featured in Wired: https://www.wired.com/story/how-to-make-public-twitter-archive/

item.title: Dorothy Bishop

New blogpost, inspired, as usual, by irritation.
http://deevybee.blogspot.com/2023/09/polyunsaturated-fatty-acids-and.html
I sometimes think the research literature is so mired by questionable research practices that there is really no hope.
#integrity #p-hacking #PublicationBias #QRPs #neurodevelopment

item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description: Never thought I would have an exam as a full professor:What do you think of modularity of mind/brain?What is a brain “area”?What is cognition?How conservative is brain evolution?What does it mean to say that networks are dynamical?How does causation work in complex systems?

item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description: ah, no idea if I passed...
